locations.name: Osama Bin Laden's Condo
locations.description: Osama Bin Laden lived here in the 1970's when he was a rich Saudi playboy

locations.name: Sutro Baths
locations.subtitle: subtitle
locations.description: On a stroll through the Sutro Bath ruins, one-armed Uncle Victor (Charles Tyner) offers morose young Harold (Bud Cort) a lesson on the joys of military service in Harold and Maude. 'Only one thing kept going through my mind. Kill! Kill for Joe and Mack and all the rest of the guys! Kill!' The 1971 feature directed by Hal Ashby is one of the cinema's greatest dark comedies. Harold is obsessed with death until he meets 79 year-old free spirit Maude. Highlights include several fake suicide attempts Harold stages to horrify his guileless mother, played by Vivian Pickles. Ruth Gordon is total perfection as Maude. San Franciscans will also appreciate one scene that exquisitely documents the former landmark collection of makeshift sculpture that used to dot the mudflats near west bound I-80 and the Bay Bridge and was for many years considered a blight by some.  -MisterSF.com

locations.name: Tommy's Joynt
locations.subtitle: subtitle
locations.description: Tommy's Joynt is the original hof-brau of San Francisco , and has become one of San Francisco's longest living institutions. We sit here at Van Ness and Geary, on Route 101, at the crossroads of the City. 'Welcome Stranger' decals itself above our front doors, front doors that beg you to come inside and eat 'Where Turkey is King.' While the City has been changing year after year, we remain steadfast in our opposition to change.  -Tommysjoynt.com

locations.name: City Lights Books
locations.subtitle: subtitle
locations.description: Founded in 1953 by poet Lawrence Ferlinghetti and Peter D. Martin, City Lights is one of the truly great independent bookstores in the United States, a place where booklovers from across the country and around the world come to browse, read, and just soak in the ambiance of alternative culture's only 'Literary Landmark.'  -citylights.com

locations.name: Cable Car Barn
locations.subtitle: subtitle
locations.description: Inside the historic Cable Car Barn & Powerhouse, visitors can view the actual cable winding machinery from an elevated gallery, as well as the path of the cable entering the building and leaving underneath the street in the sheave room viewing area.  Also on display are various mechanical devices, such as grips, track, trucks, cable and brake mechanisms with corresponding explanations.

locations.name: Clarion Alley
locations.subtitle: subtitle
locations.description: Clarion Alley Mural Project (CAMP) is an artists' collective formed in October 1992 by a volunteer collective of six North Mission residents: Aaron Noble, Michael O'Connor, Sebastiana Pastor, Rigo 92, Mary Gail Snyder, and Aracely Soriano. The project creates and facilitates other artists creating murals on Clarion Alley, between Valencia and Mission Streets and surrounding areas. -Wikipedia

locations.name: Conservatory of Flowers
locations.subtitle: subtitle
locations.description: Home to a collection of rare and exotic plants. Constructed in 1878, it is the oldest building in Golden Gate Park.

locations.name: Lombard Street
locations.subtitle: subtitle
locations.description: A famous winding road with eight hairpin turns.

locations.name: Palace of Fine Arts
locations.subtitle: subtitle
locations.description: A structure from the 1915 Panama-Pacific Exposition that exhibited works of art.

locations.name: Ferry Building
locations.subtitle: subtitle
locations.description: A ferry terminal housing a large marketplace with many shops and restaurants.

locations.name: Golden Gate Park Windmills
locations.subtitle: subtitle
locations.description: Two functionining windmills located in Golden Gate Park.

locations.name: Mission Dolores
locations.subtitle: subtitle
locations.description: The oldest surviving structure in San Francisco.

locations.name: McElroy Octagon House
locations.subtitle: subtitle
locations.description: An octagonal house built by William C. McElroy.

locations.name: Feusier Octagon House
locations.subtitle: subtitle
locations.description: An octagonal house built by George Kenny.

locations.name: Ghiradelli Square
locations.subtitle: subtitle
locations.description: A landmark with shops and restaurants. Located at Fisherman's Wharf.

locations.name: Columbus Tower
locations.subtitle: subtitle
locations.description: A mixed-use building built in a copper-green Flatiron style.

locations.name: Wave Organ
locations.subtitle: subtitle
locations.description: A collection of PVC pipes creating a musical instrument played by the waves.

locations.name: Neptune Society Columbarium
locations.subtitle: subtitle
locations.description: The only non-denominational burial place in the city that is open to the public and has space available. Hopefully you won't need it, though.

locations.name: Audium
locations.subtitle: subtitle
locations.description: A theater that pioneers the "exploration of space in music".

locations.name: Musee Mecanique
locations.subtitle: subtitle
locations.description: A museum with an extensive collection of mechanically operated musical instruments and antique arcade machines.

locations.name: Coit Tower
locations.subtitle: subtitle
locations.description: Offers great views of San Francisco.

locations.name: San Francisco Art Institute
locations.subtitle: subtitle
locations.description: One of the oldest art schools in the United States. Hosts public events and exhibits.

locations.name: California Academy of Sciences
locations.subtitle: subtitle
locations.description: A museum of natural history. One of the largest in the world.

locations.name: Metreon
locations.subtitle: Spend away!
locations.description: A shopping center with many dining and entertainment options, including a theater.
